raw_text:
Three DJs replace Peel radio show
 
 The late John Peel's BBC Radio 1 show is to be succeeded in February by three shows hosted by three DJs focusing on diverse, non-commercial music.
 
 Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame and Rob Da Bank will each host the mid-week, late-night timeslot, showcasing UK talent. Radio 1 said the show would not try to replace Peel, but would rise to the "challenge" of "keeping his legacy alive" with unpredictable music. Peel died after suffering a heart attack in Peru in October. Radio 1 said the three DJs had been chosen for their "in-depth musical knowledge across a variety of musical genres". Rob Da Bank has been hosting The John Peel Show since the DJ's death. He is also one of the hosts of The Blue Room, an early morning weekend show that plays a mix of old and new electronic and dance music. Huw Stephens is currently one half of the Radio 1 Thursday night show Bethan and Huw in Wales, which explores new music, especially up and coming acts breaking through in Wales. And Ras Kwame is the host of 100% Homegrown on Radio 1's digital station 1Xtra. His show is dedicated to showcasing the best of UK black music and broadcasts live sessions, often giving new artists their first chance to perform on live national radio.
 
 All of the three DJs will continue to host their current shows on Radio 1. "It is widely accepted that John Peel can never be replaced," said the radio station. It added that One Music would support both signed and unsigned talent, and said: "It will seek out those making music for music's sake rather than for commercial success. "Above all it will provide support to emerging genres of music and styles that have not yet and may never reach the mainstream."
 
 One Music is not new to Radio 1 as it already exists as a website, offering advice on aspects of the music industry, such as recording a demo and signing a record contract. Radio 1's controller, Andy Parfitt, said: "We believe that by having a series of DJs hosting a selection of shows under the One Music title, we will ensure that his legacy lives on." Stephens said he grew up "listening to John" and that it was a "massive honour" to continue Peel's work championing new music. The show will be broadcast from 1 February on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays from 2300 GMT - 0100 GMT.
llama3.2:1b: Three DJs are replacing the late John Peel's BBC Radio 1 show: Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank. They will host mid-week, late-night timeslots, focusing on diverse non-commercial music. The shows will not aim to replace Peel but instead rise to his legacy by showcasing unpredictable music. The DJs have been chosen for their in-depth knowledge across various genres and have hosted other popular Radio 1 shows.
llama3.2:3b: The BBC Radio 1 show succeeding John Peel's timeslot will feature three DJs hosting mid-week late-night shows showcasing diverse non-commercial music, with the goal of keeping his legacy alive. The hosts are Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank, who have been chosen for their musical knowledge across various genres.
gemma2:2b: Three DJs, Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank, will host the late-night "One Music" show replacing John Peel's BBC Radio 1 program. The shows will feature UK talent and focus on diverse genres.  The show aims to honor John Peel's legacy by supporting emerging music styles that don't traditionally reach mainstream audiences.

Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame and Rob Da Bank each host a mid-week, late-night time slot showcasing UK talent. All three DJs will continue to host their current shows on Radio 1. "One Music" website offers advice for recording demos and signing contracts, providing support to emerging genres of music. The One Music show will be broadcast from 1 February on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays from 2300 GMT - 0100 GMT.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Three DJs, Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank, have been appointed to host the John Peel Radio Show succession in February, focusing on diverse, non-commercial music, with a goal of maintaining his legacy. The show will be broadcast from 2300-0100 GMT every Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday on BBC Radio 1.
qwen2.5:3b: Three DJs—Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank—will replace the late John Peel's BBC Radio 1 show starting in February. Each will host mid-week and late-night shows focused on showcasing UK music talent. The station emphasizes these hosts' musical knowledge across various genres, with Rob Da Bank continuing his role as John Peel Show host. Stephens is known for his work in exploring new Welsh music, while Ras Kwame focuses on UK black music. One Music aims to support unsigned artists and emerging genres not yet reaching the mainstream. The show will air from 1 February on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays at 23:00 GMT - 01:00 GMT.
opencoder:1.5b:
The summary of the text is as follows:

Three DJs replace Peel radio show, followed by hosting a diverse range of musical genres on Radio 1.
 
Peel died in October, who was originally a heartbroken accident. His legacy has been steadily supported by The John Peel Show and various other shows featuring similar themes.
 
Rob Da Bank hosts The John Peel Show since his death. He is also one of the hosts of The Blue Room, an early morning weekend show with a mix of electronic and dance music.
 
Huw Stephens was part of Bethan and Huw in Wales, which explores new genres of music. Ras Kwame hosts 100% Homegrown on Radio 1's digital station 1Xtra, providing live sessions showcasing the best of UK black music.
 
The show has been broadcast from 1 February on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays for a time slot in between 23:00 GMT - 0:100 GMT.
